div.p: ENDURING STRENGTH AND ABILITY to CAUSE OTHERS to ACT:do what one DESIRES them to DO.
1. The dominant general words for power are wēi 威 "formidable authority" and shì 勢 "strategic position of power".
2. Quán 權 refers to one's political leverage or one's formal position of power.
3. Wèi 位 refers to the formal and official (usually very high) position one has in a hierarchy, but the word is occasionally also used as a general term referring to any station in life. See RANK.
4. Zhòng 重 refers to the actual political influence a person may have.
5. Shù 數 refers to a complex constellation of power as an object of assessment.
6. Shén 神 is occasionally used to refer to a supernatural or divinely sanctioned authority or political efficacy of a person.
7. Yán 嚴 refers to the formidable quality of power growing from real authority.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages
Vocabulaire européen des philosophies. Dictionnaire des intraduisibles
De differentiis

note.p: Potentia est sui cuiusque solius, potentatus vero auctoritas est iudicialis.
429. Inter potentiam et potentatum. Potentia est [col. 53C] sui cujusque solius, potentatus vero auctoritas [ Al., auctoritatis] est judicialis.

bibl.title: Lateinische Synonyme und Etymologien

note.p: potentia refers to an external power to do things which can be exerted at will.
potentatus refers to the external rank of the ruler which enables him to do certain things.
potestas refers to a just and lawful power which is invested in someone.

entry.def: Wèi 位 refers to the formal and official (usually very high) position one has in a hierarchy, but the word is occasionally also used as a general term referring to any station in life. See RANK.

sense.def: high official rank; position of power; specifically: ruler's position
(military or political) strength and influence; effective power
forced, brought about through exercise of (brute, unnatural) power
position of eminence; position of power; strategic advantage; power; clout

entry.def: Yán 嚴 refers to the formidable quality of power growing from real authority.
The dominant general words for power are wēi 威 "formidable authority" and shì 勢 "strategic position of power".

sense.def: have political authority, be politically formidable; carry natural authority
be more awesome, be more awe-inspiring
impose one's authority over. assert one's authority over; exercise autority over
(cause to be authoritative>) give authority, provide with authority
impose one's authority on the contextually determinate N
the authority/might of the contextually determinate N
become politically formidable; acquire natural authority

entry.def: Shù 數 refers to a complex constellation of power as an object of assessment.
Quán 權 refers to one's political leverage or one's formal position of power.

sense.def: leverage; political leverage, weight and power
relative leverage/impact of things; cosmic relevance; cosmic significance
天下之權"power in/over the world": power over N

entry.def: Shén 神 is occasionally used to refer to a supernatural or divinely sanctioned authority or political efficacy of a person.

sense.def: instead of 阼: position of power, power
HF 8.8.3: concentrations of power (in a state)

entry.def: Zhòng 重 refers to the actual political influence a person may have.

sense.def: political influence, political weight; political power
powerful person, political heavy-weight; "one of the big boys"
become more powerful; gain political importance
be of great political or social importance; be powerful; be politically influential; be preponderant; have great influence (with someone)
cause to be powerful; add to someone's political weight

bibl.title: 佛光大辭典 Fóguāng dàcídiǎn The Foguang Dictionary of Buddhism

sense.def: BUDDH: the Five Supernatural Powers (also referred to as wǔ shéntōng 五神通); skr. pañcābhijñā (the five powers include the following: (1)shénjìngzhì shéntōng 神境智證通 the power to freely transport oneself from one place to another (skr.ṛiddhi-viṣaya-jñāna- sākṣātkriyābhijñā; also: 神境通, 身通, 神足通, 身如意通,如意通); (2) tiānyǎnzhì tōng 天眼智通, tiānyǎntōng 天眼通 this refers to a kind of a universal vision which also sees things which are remote or in the past; (3) tiāněrzhì zhèngtōng 天耳智證通, tiāněrzhì tōng 天耳智通, tiāněr tōng 天耳通 the ability of universal hearing (skr. divya-śrotra-jñāna-sāksātkriyābhijñā)' (4) tāxīnzhì zhèngtōng 他心智證通 the ability to read the thoughts of other people (skr. cetaḥ-paryāya-jñāna-sākṣātkriyābhijñā); also referred to as 他心智通, 知他心通, 他心通; (5) sùzhù suíniànzhì zhèngtōng 宿住隨念智證通, sùzhùzhì tong1 宿住智通, shísùmìng tōng 識宿命通, sùmìng tōng 宿命通 the ability to know about past events (e.g. one's former rebirths) (skr. pūrve-nivāsānusmṛti- jñāna-sākṣātkriyābhijñā)

BUDDH: endowed with the five supernatural powers (the five powers include the following: (1)shénjìngzhì shéntōng 神境智證通 the power to freely transport oneself from one place to another (skr.ṛiddhi-viṣaya-jñāna- sākṣātkriyābhijñā; also: 神境通, 身通, 神足通, 身如意通, 如意通 ); (2) tiānyǎnzhì tōng 天眼智通, tiānyǎntōng 天眼通 this refers to a kind of a universal vision which also sees things which are remote or in the past; (3) tiāněrzhì zhèngtōng 天耳智證通, tiāněrzhì tōng 天耳智通, tiāněr tōng 天耳通 the ability of universal hearing (skr. divya-śrotra-jñāna-sāksātkriyābhijñā)' (4) tāxīnzhì zhèngtōng 他心智證通 the ability to read the thoughts of other people (skr. cetaḥ-paryāya-jñāna-sākṣātkriyābhijñā); also referred to as 他心智通, 知他心通, 他心通; (5) sùzhù suíniànzhì zhèngtōng 宿住隨念智證通, sùzhùzhì tong1 宿住智通, shísùmìng tōng 識宿命通, sùmìng tōng 宿命通 the ability to know about past events (e.g. one's former rebirths) (skr. pūrve-nivāsānusmṛti- jñāna-sākṣātkriyābhijñā)
wield power over so as to cause to shake and tremble (see 威 POWER)

bibl.title: 佛光大辭典 Fóguāng dàcídiǎn The Foguang Dictionary of Buddhism

sense.def: BUDDH: the unfathomable conduct and powers of a Bodhisattva or Buddha; skr. anubhāva
BUDDH: ?? supernatural transformation > supernatural powers/abilities (see also the more current 神通)
(= shi4 勢) in terms of political power
天下王位 (ritual) control over the (Zhou dominated) world; (ritual) control (in principle) over the whole world
power over the empire; power in the empire
